content.question: Read each question carefully. Write your response in the space provided for each part of each question. Answers must be written out in paragraph form. Outlines, bulleted lists, or diagrams alone are not acceptable and will not be scored. A student studying two different aquatic, plant-eating, unicellular protist species (species <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) designed an experiment to investigate the ecological relationship between the two species (Table <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>). TABLE 1. EXPERIMENTAL TREATMENT GROUPS In treatment group <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>, the student placed <math alttext="10" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> individuals of species <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> into a container with liquid growth medium and <math alttext="10" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> individuals of species <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> into a separate container with an equal amount of the same liquid growth medium. In treatment group <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow></mstyle><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>, the student placed <math alttext="5" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> individuals of each species into a single container with the liquid growth medium. The student then maintained the containers under the same environmental conditions and recorded the number of individuals in each population at various time points. The results are shown in Table <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. TABLE 2. NUMBER OF INDIVIDUALS IN EACH PROTIST POPULATIONIN BOTH TREATMENT GROUPS (a) The growth curves for species <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in group <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> and for species <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in group <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow></mstyle><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> (shaded columns) have been plotted on the template. Use the template to complete an appropriately labeled line graph to illustrate the growth of species <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in treatment group <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> and species <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in treatment group <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow></mstyle><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></math> (unshaded columns).

frqParts.text: Read each question carefully. Write your response in the space provided for each part of each question. Answers must be written out in paragraph form. Outlines, bulleted lists, or diagrams alone are not acceptable and will not be scored. A student studying two different aquatic, plant-eating, unicellular protist species (species <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) designed an experiment to investigate the ecological relationship between the two species (Table <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>). TABLE 1. EXPERIMENTAL TREATMENT GROUPS In treatment group <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>, the student placed <math alttext="10" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> individuals of species <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> into a container with liquid growth medium and <math alttext="10" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> individuals of species <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> into a separate container with an equal amount of the same liquid growth medium. In treatment group <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow></mstyle><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>, the student placed <math alttext="5" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> individuals of each species into a single container with the liquid growth medium. The student then maintained the containers under the same environmental conditions and recorded the number of individuals in each population at various time points. The results are shown in Table <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. TABLE 2. NUMBER OF INDIVIDUALS IN EACH PROTIST POPULATIONIN BOTH TREATMENT GROUPS (a) The growth curves for species <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in group <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> and for species <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in group <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow></mstyle><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> (shaded columns) have been plotted on the template. Use the template to complete an appropriately labeled line graph to illustrate the growth of species <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in treatment group <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> and species <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in treatment group <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow></mstyle><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></math> (unshaded columns).

(b) As shown in the table, the student established treatment group <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow></mstyle><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> with <math alttext="5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> individuals of each species. Provide reasoning for the reduced initial population sizes.

(c) The student claims that species <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> compete for the same food source. Provide TWO pieces of evidence from the data that support the studentâ€™s claim.

(d) Predict TWO factors that will most likely limit the population growth of species <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in treatment group <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(e) Many protists contain an organelle called a contractile vacuole that pumps water out of the cell. The student repeated the experiment using a growth medium with a lower solute concentration. Predict how the activity of the contractile vacuole will change under the new experimental conditions. Justify your prediction.

skill.text: 3.C: Identify experimental procedures that align with the question, including: i. identifying dependent and independent variables ii. identifying appropriate controls iii. justifying appropriate controls
